clinical_study.brief_title: E-cigarettes to Promote Smoking Reduction Among Individuals With Schizophrenia
clinical_study.official_title: E-cigarettes to Promote Smoking Reduction Among Individuals With Schizophrenia

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess if access to an electronic nicotine delivery device, or e-cigarette, in addition to nicotine patch (21 mg) can help reduce cigarette smoking among individuals diagnosed with schizophrenia compared to nicotine patch alone.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in smoking as assessed by breath Carbon Monoxide
Change in Smoking as assessed by urinary cotinine
Change in smoking as assessed by a smoking diary
Change in smoking as assessed by timeline followback

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in tobacco dependence as assessed by Fagerstrom Test for Nicotine Dependence (FTND)
Change in craving for tobacco cigarettes as assessed by the questionnaire of smoking urges (QSU)
Change in withdrawal systems from tobacco cigarettes as assessed by the Minnesota Nicotine Withdrawal Questionnaire (MNWQ)
Change in desire to quit tobacco cigarette smoking as assessed by stages of change questionnaire
Changes in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disorder (COPD) related symptoms as assessed by the clinical COPD questionnaire
Change in confidence to quit tobacco smoking as assessed by the confidence to quit questionnaire
Dependence on e-cigarettes as assessed by the e-cigarette dependence scale
Patterns of e-cigarette use as assessed by the E-cigarette patterns of use questionnaire
Satisfaction with e-cigarette as assessed by the e-cig evaluation
E-cigarette side effects as assessed by the E-cig side effects questionnaire
Change in nicotine dependence as assessed by the hooked on nicotine questionnaire (HONQ)
Change in severity of schizophrenia symptoms as assessed by the brief psychiatric rating scale (BPRS)
Changes in key cognitive domains associated with schizophrenia as assessed by the MATRICS Consensus Cognitive Battery (MCCB)
Changes in positive symptoms of schizophrenia as assessed by the Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms (SAPS)
Changes in negative symptoms of schizophrenia as assessed by the Scale for the Assessment of Negative Symptoms (SANS)
Changes in suicide ideation as assessed by the Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (CSSRS)

arm_group.description: Participants will receive nicotine patch (21 mg) starting study Week 1. Participants will be instructed to apply a new patch each morning.

The e-cigarette will consist of 1) a 3.3 V, 1000 mAh battery; and 2) a 1.5 Ohm, dual-coil cartomizer (SmokTech; Shenzhen, China). Study staff will load the cartomizer with 1 ml tobacco flavored 70% propylene glycol/30% vegetable glycerin liquid containing nicotine concentrations 36 mg/ml (AVAIL; Richmond, Virginia, USA).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Be diagnosed with schizophrenia
- Be in stable medical condition (DSM-V)
- report smoking ≥10 tobacco cigarettes/day
- present a breath CO ≥10 ppm
- report wanting to reduce their cigarette smoking
- be fluent in English
- have a stable living situation
Exclusion Criteria:
- be currently pregnant or breastfeeding
- report wanting to quit smoking in the immediate future
- test positive for illicit drugs except THC
- have any illness, medical condition, or use of medications, which in the opinion of the study physicians would preclude safe and/or successful completion of the study
